Terminology

Send comments on this topic.
These terms are used through the FlashFX product and documentation and a thorough understanding is critical to productively using the product.

Basic Flash Memory Terms

Erase Block

The smallest flash element which may be erased. This is typically a value which may be as small as 16KB for small-block NAND, ranging to 128KB for standard large-block NAND and up to 512KB or more for some designs.

FlashFX typically uses the term "block" by itself to refer to an erase block.

Page

The standard minimum programmable size for NAND flash. For small-block NAND this value is typically 512 bytes, while standard large-block NAND uses has 2048 bytes per page. Larger page sizes are available in some designs.

For NOR flash, FlashFX will use an emulated page, typically 512 bytes.

Spare Area

For NAND flash, this is an associated number of extra bytes for each page which may be used to store such metadata as the ECC, bad block markers, and the FlashFX Tag.

FlashFX will only function on NAND flash which has at least two bytes available in the spare area for its Tag.

XIP

Refers to the ability to eXecute-In-Place, where code can be directly executed out of flash, rather than first requiring the code to be copied into RAM. NOR supports XIP, while NAND does not.

FlashFX Specific Terminology

Device

A term which is used to refer to an area of flash which has been made available by a FIM. A FlashFX Device is often a single chip, though FIMs/NTMs may group similar chips together to make one larger virtual chip. FlashFX numbers Devices from to zero to FFX_MAX_DEVICES, and uses the notation DEV0, DEV1, etc.

Disk

A Disk is a mapping of some number of erase blocks on a Device or a range of Devices. All OEM access to the flash is done via function calls which take a Disk handle. FlashFX numbers Disks from to zero to FFX_MAX_DISKS, and uses the notation DISK0, DISK1, etc.

Tag

A FlashFX term referring to the metadata which FlashFX stores in the spare area when using NAND flash.

FlashFX Hooks

FlashFX provides an abstracted set of functions which may be implemented in the Project Directory, which can be used to override the default FlashFX functionality for certain operations. These hooks are sometimes called Project Hooks.

Allocator

The FlashFX Allocator is the portion of FlashFX which provides the virtual-to-physical translation of logical Disk sectors to physical flash pages.

FIM

A FIM (Flash Interface Module) contains the low level algorithms to read, write, and erase the flash, along with other low level operations. It may support a single flash chip, a family of chips, or multiple types of flash, just depending on how similar their characteristics are.

NTM

An NTM (NAND Technology Module) is used to abstract access to the physical NAND interface for the NAND FIM.
